title: Near drowning after mum turns back ‘just a few seconds’

locations.name: st. media_camera residents of the seven hills

text: Help for drug-addicted mums A THREE-year-old boy was under water “for some time’’ before being pulled out of an unfenced above-ground swimming pool. The boy’s mother was at home with her son and his four siblings when he was found unresponsive in the pool of the June St home about noon. Neighbours told reporters the mother had turned her back for “just a few seconds” to grab an ice block when the boy flipped on his floatie into the pool face first. A neighbour performed CPR at the scene until paramedics arrived. A woman whose daughter performed CPR was left “distraught” and “not in the right state of mind” after the incident. An Ambulance NSW spokesman said: “He would have been submerged in water for some time.’’ media_camera Police at the house where the boy was found in the pool. Picture: Adam Ward media_camera The unfenced pool where the three-year-old was found submerged. Picture: Channel 7 The boy, who is a twin, was found face down and placed into an induced coma before he was rushed to the Children’s Hospital at Westmead. media_camera A woman and child at the house in June St. media_camera Residents of the Seven Hills street where the incident occurred. A CareFlight helicopter was also dispatched to the scene. The boy was rushed to hospital in a serious condition. The pool is in a backyard not unlike many suburban family homes. It just a few metres from the back door of the home and near a cubby house and trampoline. A neighbour was left shaken after hearing the news. She often sees the victim and his siblings playing outside on their bicycles. “This is devastating; I can’t imagine what the parents are going through.” Kate, did not want to give her surname, said. Royal Life Saving NSW chief executive officer David Macallister said parents were warned to be vigilant when their children were swimming. “Firstly parents should remain vigilant at all times and it is extremely important for those parents to be extremely aware whenever their children are in or near the water,’ Mr Macallister said. He said portable swimming pools must be treated as an in-ground pools and should be fenced according to local council guidelines if they are over 30cm tall. “Any parcel of water that is deeper than 30cm should be fenced,” and once those pools are no longer in use, they must be “tipped and emptied before being turned upside down to ensure the child isn’t attracted to go back into the pool”. “It is super important parents know CPR because we know that if you start resuscitation immediately there’s a very good chance that you will keep that person alive.” media_camera
